author: Grimms
text: Once upon a time there was a widow who had two daughters; one of them was beautiful and industrious, the other ugly and lazy.

author: Grimms
text: The mother, however, loved the ugly and lazy one best, because she was her own daughter, and so the other, who was only her stepdaughter, was made to do all the work of the house, and was quite the Cinderella of the family.

author: Grimms
text: Her stepmother sent her out every day to sit by the well in the high road, there to spin until she made her fingers bleed.

author: Grimms
text: Now it chanced one day that some blood fell on to the spindle, and as the girl stopped over the well to wash it off, the spindle suddenly sprang out of her hand and fell into the well.

author: Grimms
text: She ran home crying to tell of her misfortune, but her stepmother spoke harshly to her, and after giving her a violent scolding, said unkindly, "As you have let the spindle fall into the well you may go yourself and fetch it out."

author: Grimms
text: The girl went back to the well not knowing what to do, and at last in her distress she jumped into the water after the spindle.

author: Grimms
text: She remembered nothing more until she awoke and found herself in a beautiful meadow, full of sunshine, and with countless flowers blooming in every direction.

author: Grimms
text: She walked over the meadow, and presently she came upon a baker"s oven full of bread, and the loaves cried out to her, "Take us out, take us out, or alas! we shall be burnt to a cinder; we were baked through long ago."

author: Grimms
text: So she took the bread-shovel and drew them all out.

author: Grimms
text: She went on a little farther, till she came to a free full of apples.

author: Grimms
text: "Shake me, shake me, I pray," cried the tree; "my apples, one and all, are ripe."

author: Grimms
text: So she shook the tree, and the apples came falling down upon her like rain; but she continued shaking until there was not a single apple left upon it.

author: Grimms
text: Then she carefully gathered the apples together in a heap and walked on again.

author: Grimms
text: The next thing she came to was a little house, and there she saw an old woman looking out, with such large teeth, that she was terrified, and turned to run away.

author: Grimms
text: But the old woman called after her, "What are you afraid of, dear child?

author: Grimms
text: Stay with me; if you will do the work of my house properly for me, I will make you very happy.

author: Grimms
text: You must be very careful, however, to make my bed in the right way, for I wish you always to shake it thoroughly, so that the feathers fly about; then they say, down there in the world, that it is snowing; for I am Mother Holle."

author: Grimms
text: The old woman spoke so kindly, that the girl summoned up courage and agreed to enter into her service.

author: Grimms
text: She took care to do everything according to the old woman"s bidding and every time she made the bed she shook it with all her might, so that the feathers flew about like so many snowflakes.

author: Grimms
text: The old woman was as good as her word: she never spoke angrily to her, and gave her roast and boiled meats every day.

author: Grimms
text: So she stayed on with Mother Holle for some time, and then she began to grow unhappy.

author: Grimms
text: She could not at first tell why she felt sad, but she became conscious at last of great longing to go home; then she knew she was homesick, although she was a thousand times better off with Mother Holle than with her mother and sister.

author: Grimms
text: After waiting awhile, she went to Mother Holle and said, "I am so homesick, that I cannot stay with you any longer, for although I am so happy here, I must return to my own people."

author: Grimms
text: Then Mother Holle said, "I am pleased that you should want to go back to your own people, and as you have served me so well and faithfully, I will take you home myself."

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon she led the girl by the hand up to a broad gateway.

author: Grimms
text: The gate was opened, and as the girl passed through, a shower of gold fell upon her, and the gold clung to her, so that she was covered with it from head to foot.

author: Grimms
text: "That is a reward for your industry," said Mother Holle, and as she spoke she handed her the spindle which she had dropped into the well.

author: Grimms
text: The gate was then closed, and the girl found herself back in the old world close to her mother"s house.

author: Grimms
text: As she entered the courtyard, the cock who was perched on the well, called out:

author: Grimms
text: "Cock-a-doodle-doo!

author: Grimms
text: Your golden daughter"s come back to you."

author: Grimms
text: Then she went in to her mother and sister, and as she was so richly covered with gold, they gave her a warm welcome.

author: Grimms
text: She related to them all that had happened, and when the mother heard how she had come by her great riches, she thought she should like her ugly, lazy daughter to go and try her fortune.

author: Grimms
text: So she made the sister go and sit by the well and spin, and the girl pricked her finger and thrust her hand into a thorn-bush, so that she might drop some blood on to the spindle; then she threw it into the well, and jumped in herself.

author: Grimms
text: Like her sister she awoke in the beautiful meadow, and walked over it till she came to the oven.

author: Grimms
text: "Take us out, take us out, or alas! we shall be burnt to a cinder; we were baked through long ago," cried the loaves as before.

author: Grimms
text: But the lazy girl answered, "Do you think I am going to dirty my hands for you?" and walked on.

author: Grimms
text: Presently she came to the apple-tree.

author: Grimms
text: "Shake me, shake me, I pray; my apples, one and all, are ripe," it cried.

author: Grimms
text: But she only answered, "A nice thing to ask me to do, one of the apples might fall on my head," and passed on.

author: Grimms
text: At last she came to Mother Holle"s house, and as she had heard all about the large teeth from her sister, she was not afraid of them, and engaged herself without delay to the old woman.

author: Grimms
text: The first day she was very obedient and industrious, and exerted herself to please Mother Holle, for she thought of the gold she should get in return.

author: Grimms
text: The next day, however, she began to dawdle over her work, and the third day she was more idle still; then she began to lie in bed in the mornings and refused to get up.

author: Grimms
text: Worse still, she neglected to make the old woman"s bed properly, and forgot to shake it so that the feathers might fly about.

author: Grimms
text: So Mother Holle very soon got tired of her, and told her she might go.

author: Grimms
text: The lazy girl was delighted at this, and thought to herself, "The gold will soon be mine."

author: Grimms
text: Mother Holle led her, as she had led her sister, to the broad gateway; but as she was passing through, instead of the shower of gold, a great bucketful of pitch came pouring over her.

author: Grimms
text: "That is in return for your services," said the old woman, and she shut the gate.

author: Grimms
text: So the lazy girl had to go home covered with pitch, and the cock on the well called out as she saw her:

author: Grimms
text: "Cock-a-doodle-doo!

author: Grimms
text: Your dirty daughter"s come back to you."

author: Grimms
text: But, try what she would, she could not get the pitch off and it stuck to her as long as she lived.
